questions.text: Baby is able to roll on opposite side at what age?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

5-7 months

Highyeild:

Rolling over is a significant motor milestone in infant development. Most babies learn to roll from their back to stomach at around 5 to 6 months. Rolling from stomach to back typically follows around 6 to 7 months. Tummy time helps in developing rolling skills and upper body strength. Individual variation exists, and some babies may achieve rolling milestones earlier or later. Rolling is an important precursor to other motor milestones like sitting, crawling, and walking.

Table:

#MANTRA Age Gross motor Fine motor Language Social/Cognitive 2 months ● Raises head and chest when prone ● Follows objects past midline ● Coos ● Smiles back (social smile) ● Recognizes parents 4 months ● Holds head straight ● Rolls over front to back ● Props himself/herself up on wrists in prone position ● Holds and shakes rattle ● Laughs ● Makes consonant sounds ● Localizes sound 6 months ● Sits without support ● Rolls over back to the front ● Grabs objects ● Raking grasp ● Babbles ● Develops stranger anxiety (6–9 months) ● Develops object permanence (6–9 months) 9 months ● Crawls ● Stands when holding on to something ● Pincer grasps (9-12 months) ● transfers objects from one hand to the other ● Says “ma-ma”, “da-da” ● Orients to name ● Imitates actions ● Has separation anxiety 12 months ● Starts to walk ● Can throw objects ● Points at objects ● Knows 1–5 words ● Follows simple commands

questions.text: At which age a child’s height is half of his expected adult height?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

18-24 month Height is half to his/her adult height 20 months for a girl and 24 months for a boy. That's because by 2 y/o, most children have reached the growth chart percentile they will stay on as they grow. The average height at age 2 is, in fact, about half of the average adult height, and the correlation between height at 2 and height in adulthood is about 0.75 for boys and 0.65 for girls

Highyeild:

A child's height is about half of their expected adult height by 18 to 24 months. Growth velocity is highest during infancy and early childhood. Genetics, nutrition, and health influence a child's ultimate height. Pediatricians use growth charts to monitor and compare a child's growth. Regular check-ups are crucial to ensure healthy development.

Extraedge:

Normal Height increases per year (Linear Growth Velocity): Birth length Average: birth length: 20 inches (50 cm) Length doubles by age 4 years Length triples by age 13 years First year growth: 9-11 inches (23-27 cm) Second year growth: 4-6 inches (10-14 cm) Third year growth: 3-4 inches (7.5 - 10 cm) Annual growth until Puberty : 2-3 inches (6-7 cm) Prepuberty growth: 2 inches (5 cm) Pubertal growth Boys: 4-6 inches (10-14 cm) Girls: 3-5 inches (8-12 cm)

Table:

#MANTRA Age Average Height Increase per Year (Linear Growth Velocity) Birth 0 inches (0 cm) 1 year 9-11 inches (23-27 cm) 2 years 4-6 inches (10-14 cm) 3 years 3-4 inches (7.5 - 10 cm) 4 years Length doubles (20 inches to 40 inches / 50 cm to 100 cm) 13 years Length triples (20 inches to 60 inches / 50 cm to 150 cm) Annual growth until puberty 2-3 inches (6-7 cm) Prepuberty 2 inches (5 cm) Pubertal growth (Boys) 4-6 inches (10-14 cm) Pubertal growth (Girls) 3-5 inches (8-12 cm)

questions.text: In a child, CSF examination is not used in diagnosis of:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hodgkin's lymphoma Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL), Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma and Acute Myeloid Leukemia disseminate via CSF. So, CSF examination can be used in the diagnosis. Prophylactic craniospinal irradiation is used in the treatment In Hodgkin s lymphoma, there is no CSF spread, so CSF examination is not used in the diagnosis.

Highyeild:

Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF) Examination : It is a diagnostic procedure that analyzes the fluid surrounding the brain and spinal cord. Purpose : CSF examination is used to diagnose various neurological conditions and infections affecting the central nervous system (CNS). Diagnostic Applications : It aids in the diagnosis of meningitis, encephalitis, CNS involvement in leukemia/lymphoma, subarachnoid hemorrhage, and other neurological disorders. Components Analyzed: CSF examination includes assessing the appearance, cell count (white and red blood cells), glucose levels, protein levels, and microbiological testing.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION A: Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) : CSF examination is commonly performed in children with ALL to assess for central nervous system (CNS) involvement, which is a known complication of the disease. Presence of leukemic cells in the CSF (CNS leukemia) indicates CNS involvement and affects treatment decisions. OPTION B: Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML): CSF examination may be performed in children with AML to evaluate for CNS involvement similar to ALL. OPTION C: Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma: CSF examination may be used to assess for CNS involvement in non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, especially if there are neurological symptoms or signs.

Extraedge:

Abnormal Cells: Abnormal cells found in the CSF may indicate certain types of cancers. Infections : CSF examination can detect the presence of bacteria, viruses, or fungi in cases of infectious CNS diseases. Lumbar Puncture : The procedure is performed by collecting a small amount of CSF through a lumbar puncture (spinal tap). Clinical Significance: CSF examination provides crucial information for patient management and treatment decisions.

questions.text: Match the milestones mentioned in Column A with their approximate age of appearance in Column B: Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1-A, 2-C, 3-D, 4-B

Highyeild:

Social Smile: Milestone: The baby responds to social interactions with a smile. Approximate Age of Appearance: A. 1-2 months Mature Pincer Grasp: Milestone: The baby can pick up small objects using the thumb and index finger in a coordinated manner. Approximate Age of Appearance: B. 5-6 months Walks 1-2 Steps: Milestone: The baby takes a few steps with support. Approximate Age of Appearance: C. 9-11 months Transfers Object Hand to Hand: Milestone: The baby can pass an object from one hand to the other. Approximate Age of Appearance: D. 12-13 months

questions.text: Which of the following does not establish a diagnosis of congenital CMV infection in a neonate ?

options.label: D
options.text: CMV viral DNA in blood by polymerase chain reaction

questions.correct_answer: C. IgG CMV antibodies in blood
questions.explanation:
Solution:

IgG CMV antibodies in blood -Ig G antibody test is of little diagnostic value as positive results also reflects maternal antibodies. - Diagnosis of congenital CMV is confirmed by a positive Ig M in the first two weeks of life( However has low sensitivity and negative IgM does not rule out CMV) Detection of CMV in urine or blood is more sensitive Demonstration of cytomegalic inclusion bodies in haematoxylin and eosin sections is sufficient for a diagnosis of CMV hepatitis Congenital CMV infection cannot be diagnosed using samples collected more than three weeks after birth because testing after this time cannot distinguish between congenital infection and an infection acquired during or after delivery.

Highyeild:

About 20-30% of congenital CMV infections are symptomatic. The classic triad of SNHL, periventricular calcifications, and enamel hypoplasia is not consistently seen in all cases. Most children with asymptomatic CMV infection at birth can develop sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) later in life. If the mother has IgG positive for CMV, the child is still at risk of developing congenital CMV infection; immunity in the mother does not guarantee complete protection.

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: Causes of seizures in neonates include: Hyponatremia Hypernatremia Hypocalcemia Hypomagnesemia Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 2, 3 and 4 Acute and/or severe electrolyte imbalances can manifest with rapidly progressive neurologic symptoms or seizures, which may be the sole presenting symptom. Seizures are more frequently observed in patients with sodium disorders (especially hyponatremia), hypocalcemia, and hypomagnesaemia. Since electrolyte disturbances are, at least in the early stages, generally not associated with morphologic changes in CNS, the neurologic manifestations are typically reversible. However, seizures and the electrolyte disturbance itself can lead to structural alterations, so that the underlying electrolyte disturbances should be recognized and treated before the brain tissue injury becomes permanent. Disorders of sodium and osmolality can be responsible for an encephalopathy characterized by depression of neuronal activity, with confusion, headache, psychomotor slowing and lethargy as the major clinical manifestations, usually associated with signs of irritability. Hypercalcemia and hypermagnesemia may also produce both a neuronal depression with encephalopathy and neuronal irritability. Hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia lead almost exclusively to CNS irritability clinically manifesting with seizures, whereas disorders of potassium rarely produce symptoms in the CNS, with muscle weakness being their major clinical manifestation.

Highyeild:

Causes of Seizures in Neonates: Hyponatremia : Low levels of sodium in the blood can lead to seizures in neonates. Hypernatremia: High levels of sodium in the blood can also cause seizures in neonates. Hypocalcemia: Low levels of calcium in the blood can be a cause of seizures in neonates. Hypomagnesemia : Low levels of magnesium in the blood can contribute to seizures in neonates.

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: Child came with hemophilus influenza meningitis and was decided to give cephalosporin instead of ampicillin. What is the reason for this?

options.label: A
options.text: H. Influence has penicillin binding protein

questions.explanation:
Solution:

It has beta lactamase Intrinsic efflux resistance mechanisms in Hemophilus influenza type B limit the activity of the macrolides, azalides, and ketolides. β-Lactamase production is highly prevalent worldwide and is associated with resistance to ampicillin and amoxicillin. Strains with alterations in penicillin binding proteins, particularly PBP3 (β-lactamase negative ampicillin resistant and β-lactamase positive amoxicillin-clavulanate resistant), are increasing in prevalence, with increasing resistance to ampicillin, amoxicillin, amoxicillin-clavulanate, and many cephalosporins, limiting the efficacy of expanded-spectrum cephalosporins against meningitis and of many oral cephalosporins against other diseases. Most strains remain susceptible to the carbapenems, which are not affected by penicillin binding protein changes, and the quinolones. Influenzae type b is a common bacterial cause of childhood pneumonia and bacteremia between 6 months and 5 years of age. High-dose amoxicillin (90 mg/kg of body weight/day), either alone or with the addition of clavulanic acid, is the first-line drug of choice for empirical treatment of outpatients with childhood pneumonia. Recommended empirical therapy for inpatients includes ceftriaxone or cefotaxime to provide coverage for non-penicillin-susceptible Streptococcus pneumoniae and β-lactamase-positive H. influenzae.

Highyeild:

Hemophilus influenzae is known to produce beta-lactamase , an enzyme that can inactivate penicillin and related antibiotics. Cephalosporins are less susceptible to beta-lactamase and are more effective against beta-lactamase-producing bacteria like Hemophilus influenzae.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION A. H. Influenzae has penicillin binding protein: Hemophilus influenzae is a bacteria that possesses penicillin binding proteins, but this is not the primary reason for choosing cephalosporin. OPTION C. Cephalosporin has better absorbance: Absorbance is not the primary concern in choosing cephalosporin over ampicillin in Hemophilus influenzae meningitis. OPTION D. Child is sensitive to sulfamethazone: Sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim (sulfamethazone) is not the drug of choice for treating Hemophilus influenzae meningitis.

Extraedge:

Using a cephalosporin like cefotaxime or ceftriaxone is preferred in cases of Hemophilus influenzae meningitis due to its better activity against beta-lactamase-producing strains of the bacteria. Ampicillin, on the other hand, may be ineffective against beta-lactamase-producing Hemophilus influenzae.
